sols_html:
Here, the limit being 0 means that we simply need to show that given any \(\epsilon >0\) there exists a number \(N_\epsilon\) such that

\[\begin{aligned} \left| \frac{1-2\cos(n)}{n} \right| < \epsilon\end{aligned}\]

for any value of \(n\) larger than \(N_\epsilon\).

Since we have that

\[\begin{aligned} -1 \leq \cos(n) \leq 1\end{aligned}\]

we can multiply everywhere by -2 and obtain that

\[\begin{aligned} 2 \geq -2\cos(n) \geq -2\end{aligned}\]

and add 1 everywhere to obtain

\[\begin{aligned} 3 \geq 1-2\cos(n) \geq -1\end{aligned}\]

which now allows us to conclude about the size of \(1-2\cos(n)\) in absolute value:

\[\begin{aligned} | 1-2 \cos (n) |\leq 3\end{aligned}\]

So we can conclude that

\[\begin{aligned} \left| \frac{1-2\cos(n)}{n} \right| &= \frac{|1-2\cos(n)|}{n}\\ &\leq \frac{3}{n}\\ &< \epsilon\end{aligned}\]

for any value of \(n\) that is larger than \(N_\epsilon = 3/\epsilon\); this concludes our proof.
